There are limited renewable sources of aromatic chemicals, with lignin being one of the most prominent, accounting for approximately 30% of the planet's organic carbon. Due to its intricate and irregular structure, lignin is recalcitrant to chemical conversion, often resulting in low yields of mixtures of products when it is depolymerized. This study synthesized a CeO2/AC catalyst via an impregnation technique and then explored its ability to depolymerize lignin via an oxidation-reduction strategy. The CeO2/AC catalyst efficiently depolymerized lignin by an oxidation-reduction strategy. At 200 °C, an argon pressure of 1 MPa, and a reaction time of 4 h, the conversion of the lignin model compound reached 98.5%. When using lignin derived from poplar, birch, pine, and cotton stalk, the total yields of phenolic monomers were 36.2 wt.%, 31.2 wt.%, 17.4 wt.%, and 12.1 wt.%, respectively. The CeO2/AC catalyst exhibited a higher surface oxygen vacancy concentration than CeO2, which was crucial for facilitating the hydrogenolysis of lignin. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lignin Depolymerization Catalytic hydrogenolysis Cerium oxide Oxygen vacancies Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Lignin is one of the few natural polymers that can be used to produce aromatic precursors, which are mainly produced from petroleum resources [1]. Approximately 50 million tons of lignin are derived from pulping and bioethanol processes worldwide each year, which can be used to obtain lignin [2]. Lignin is the second most abundant polymer and an important component of lignocellulose [3]. Its monomers include eugenol (S), guaiacyl (G), and p-hydroxyphenyl (H), which are also important phenolic monomers in biomass [4]. However, technical lignin is often discarded as waste during industrial processes due to the poor yields of the target products. Aromatic platform compounds are primarily produced through thermochemical methods, including pyrolysis [5], hydrogenolysis [6], and oxidation [7]. It's significant that β-O-4 bond is the most abundant C-O aryl ether bond type in lignin [8,9]. Lignin hydrogenolysis is one of the most common and effective strategies for producing aromatic compounds and has recently become an attractive technology for lignin valorization. However, this process requires high-pressure hydrogenolysis, which results in safety concerns. In addition, H2 is mainly produced by the steam-reforming of fossil fuels. This type of gray hydrogen has a much greater carbon footprint than green hydrogen [10], making the conversion of renewable lignin unsustainable. Hydrogenolysis is one of the key steps during the conversion of biomass and its derivatives into valuable biofuels and chemicals [11–13]. The selective cracking of ether bonds using non-precious-metal catalysts is the key to ensuring the stability of lignin [14]. The catalytic depolymerization of lignin to produce value-added chemicals often suffers from limited mass transfer over heterogeneous catalysts, complex aromatic biopolymer structures, and high recalcitrance of C-C bonds [15]. Moreover, lignin hydrogenolysis into aromatic chemicals also requires high temperatures (>200 °C) and high hydrogen pressures (>2 MPa) [10]. In contrast, liquid-phase hydrogen transfer reactions use solvents such as methanol to hydrogenate lignin under relatively mild conditions without using hydrogen under high-temperature and high-pressure situations. Precious metal catalysts show excellent performance during the catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin, but their limited reserves restrict their large-scale applications [16]. Therefore, non-noble-metal catalysts show more development potential than precious metal catalysts [17], but they also show lower activities and worse selectivity during the hydrogenolysis of lignin. The synergistic effect of the non-precious metal active component and the carrier may significantly improve the catalytic activity. For example, A attapulgite supported Co-Mo bimetallic catalysts (Co-Mo/ATP-CZO, for short) were used to catalyze the depolymerization of lignin in ethanol and isopropanol. Doping Mo changed the metallic oxide phase, which increased the number of oxygen vacancies, improved metal-carrier interactions, and decreased the acid site content. Experimental results have demonstrated that catalytic hydrogenation over 12Mo-20Co/ATP-CZO catalyst at 240 °C for eight hours produced the maximum yield of bio-oil (57.44 wt%, including 37.58 wt.% of monomer) [18]. Ni/MgO catalyst converted 93.4% of lignin into 15.0% monophenols. Notably, 42.3% of these volatile chemicals were 4-ethyl phenol (the yield was 6.31%), but the process required a temperature of 270 °C [19]. Bimetallic Ni-Fe/CeO2-Al2O3 catalysts with different Ni/Fe ratios were prepared by reduction to determine the optimal Ni/Fe ratio for depolymerization [20]. The catalytic process of micro-porous biochar (BC) derived from lignin-supported Ni-Ce catalysts (xNi-Ce/BC) coupled with an aqueous solution of glycerol medium was reported for the depolymerization of Kraft lignin to guaiacol and 4-alkyl guaiacols [21]. As a catalytic support, activated carbon (AC) offers excellent porosity and surface area [22]. Cerium substantially impacts the depolymerization of lignin [23], and it is speculated that cerium oxide and activated carbon may have a powerful synergistic effect. Cerium oxide is a widely-used lanthanide metal oxide with excellent redox activity and can serve as an oxygen buffer [24,25]. The crystal structure of CeO2 is similar to that of fluorite (CaF2) and has a face-centered cubic unit cell. Due to the presence of numerous oxygen vacancies in its crystal cells and its reversible +3 and +4 valences ions, Ce3+ and Ce4+ are prone to cyclic changes, allowing cerium dioxide to store and release oxygen via the formation of surface oxygen vacancies [26]. Therefore, CeO2 has flexible oxygen absorption and release performance and a strong redox ability [27]. The use of carbon carriers can improve the dispersibility of active metals and enhance the activity of metal ions [28]. Loading CeO2 onto a carbon carrier can significantly enhance its redox ability, thus enhancing its catalytic activity. This paper loaded cerium oxide onto activated carbon (CeO2/AC) to develop a catalyst using a simple impregnation method. The resulting catalyst efficiently hydrogenated lignin under an inert atmosphere and mild conditions, and then the efficient catalytic depolymerization of lignin was realized by a two-step method. During hydrogenolysis of the Cβ-O ether bonds in lignin, the catalyst selectively cracked the β-O-4 bond instead of hydrogenating the aromatic ring and forming Cα-OH. This resulted in a high yield of low-weight aromatic compounds. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Material preparation Ce(NO3)4·(H2O)6, bromoacetone, phenol, guaiacol, and other reagents were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation (Shanghai, China). All chemicals were used as received without further purification. The activated carbon (40–60 mesh) was heated to reflux with 1 M hydrochloric acid for 2 h to remove impurities, and then washed with deionized water to neutrality and vacuum dried at 60 °C for 8 h. Several lignin model molecules, including 2-phenoxy-1-phenylacetone and 2-phenoxy-1-phenyl ethanol, were synthesized using previously reported methods with minor adjustments [29–31]. Details are provided in the Supporting Information (SI). Lignin was extracted from birch harvested from the countryside around Changji (Xinjiang, China). After air-dried birch wood chips were crushed into particles < 100 mesh and extracted with acetone to remove pigments, waxes, and other extractable substances. Detailed extraction methods are described in the SI. 2.2 Catalyst preparation CeO2/AC was prepared by an equal volume impregnation method. Different amounts of Ce(NO3)4·(H2O)6 and 2 g of activated carbon (short for AC) were impregnated in equal volumes for 12 h and then dried overnight in an oven at 110 °C. The samples were then heated at 450 °C for 1 h at a rate of 5 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. The preparation methods of other metal oxide catalysts such as MgAlOx/AC, Al2O3/AC, Pr6O11/AC, and Nd2O3/AC were similar to that of the CeO2/AC catalyst. Those catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method, using aluminum nitrate, magnesium oxide, aluminum nitrate, praseodymium nitrate, and neodymium nitrate as precursors, respectively. 10% Pd/C and 10% Ni/C were commercial catalysts purchased from Adamas. 2.3 Lignin depolymerization experiment In a typical experiment, 0.2 mmol of lignin model molecule, 0.02 g of catalyst, and 25 ml of methanol were put into a high-pressure stainless-steel autoclave (100 ml, Beijing Century Senlang Instrument Co., Ltd., Beijing, China). Then, the autoclave was flushed three times with argon gas and heated to 493 K at a rate of 5 K/min. The reaction was conducted at 493 K for 8 h with a stirring speed of 300 rpm. When the reaction was finished, the reactor was immersed in ice water and then cooled to room temperature. The liquid products in the reactor were analyzed via HPLC (Shimadzu LC-20A) and GC-MS (Agilent 7890b-5977a). The conversion and selectivity of the substrate were calculated according to the following equations: C o n v e r s i o n = m o l e s o f c o n v e r t e d s u b s t r a t e m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e × 100 ( % ) Y i e l d = m o l e s o f t h e p r o d u c t t o t a l m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e × 100 ( % ) The lignin monomer yield was calculated based on the GC peak area using dodecane as the internal standard. Additional computational details are given in the SI. Because the Cβ-O bond energy in β-O-4 ketones is about 40–50 kJ/mol lower than that of β-O-4 bonds in alcohols, the Cα-OH group of a β-O-4-ol is usually pre-oxidized to Cα=O, which is easier to depolymerize [32]. This kind of lignin is called pre-oxidized lignin. The Stahl group used 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) to selectively convert almost all Cα-OH into its corresponding ketone, as shown in Scheme 1 [33]. In the second step of converting the β-O-4-one, the catalyst-free and oxidation pathways are often used to avoid reverse conversion into the β-O-4 alcohol. This process was used to pre-oxidize the sample lignin in this paper. 2.4 Analysis methods 2.4.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The samples’ crystal structures were characterized by a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer with Cu Kα (40 kV, 100 mA) radiation. The diffracted intensity of the Cu Kα radiation = 0.15046 nm was measured in the 2θ range of 10–90o with a scanning speed of 10° min−1 and an operating current of 20 mA. After the test, the exported data was further analyzed using MDI Jade 6. 2.4.2 Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) The determination of noble metal loading and carrier cerium content in the catalyst was carried out by ICP-AES (Vista-MPX, Varian). The sample powder to be analyzed was heated in aqua regia at 90 °C for 30 min, and then the solution was slowly heated until all solvent was evaporated. Then, the residue was diluted with 5% dilute nitric acid and filtered into a 25 ml volumetric flask, and the filtride was analyzed using ICP-AES. 2.4.3 H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) Samples were characterized using an AutoChem-2920 chemisorption apparatus by heating in an H2 (5 vol.%)/Ar flow rate of 20 ml·min−1 and a heating rate of 10 K· min−1 from 303 to 1073 K. The amount of hydrogen consumed by 100 mg of sample was examined by a thermo-conductivity detector (TCD). After the first H2-TPR analysis, Ar flow was used to cool the samples to 623 K, and O2 flow was applied to re-oxidize the samples for 30 min at 623 K. To investigate the stability of samples, H2-TPR analysis was conducted three times under the same conditions as the first analysis. 2.4.4 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) Samples were analyzed by a Tecnai F30 TEM operated at an accelerating voltage of 30 kV. The sample to be analyzed was dispersed in anhydrous ethanol, and then the ethanol-dispersed sample was sonicated for 15 min. Ethanol was absorbed using a rubber dropper, carefully added to a copper mesh, quickly dried under an infrared lamp, and then placed in the TEM. 2.4.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The valence state of oxygen atoms in metal oxides was determined by XPS on a PHI-Quantum 2000, using Al Kα as the excitation source (hν = 1486.6 eV) and was operated at 15 kV and 20 mA. The test results were corrected by using the C 1s binding energy of 284.6 eV. 2.4.6 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) SEM was used to characterize the samples' surface morphology, surface element content, and surface elemental distribution. First, the sample to be tested was ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol, and then the dispersion was loaded onto a conductive silicon wafer and fixed on an SEM stage with conductive tape. LEO 1530 scanning electron microscope was used for testing. Test conditions: 15–20 kV accelerating voltage. In particular, 20 kV acceleration voltage maintains a working distance of about 8.5 mm during element scanning analysis. 2.4.7 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption (BET) The surface area, pore size, and pore volume were determined by the N2 Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained at -196 °C using a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 instrument. Samples were degassed at 300 °C for 4 h before measurements. The specific surface area was calculated according to the BET method. The average pore size and pore size distribution were determined by the Barret-Joyner-Halenda method using the desorption branch of the isotherms. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts To accurately determine the cerium content, CeO2/AC was characterized by ICP-AES. According to the ICP results shown in Table S2, the cerium content in CeO2/AC was 18.55 wt.% before use. The catalyst was used for lignin depolymerization, and then the cerium content was determined again after cleaning and calcination, which was determined to be 18.01%. The cerium content decreased slightly, which was attributed to its loss during a post-reaction process or its leaching during the reaction. However, from the perspective of the magnitude of reduction, it also showed that the amount of coke formed during lignin depolymerization was small. BET characterization of activated carbon and CeO2/AC samples was carried out to explore changes in activated carbon's physical structure before and after being loaded onto the catalyst. Details of the nitrogen adsorption-desorption curve of activated carbon and CeO2/AC are shown in Fig. S4, and specific results are listed in Table S3. The specific surface area of activated carbon was 1096.72 m2·g−1, which decreased to 711.38 m2·g−1 after loading the cerium oxide active component. The pore volume and pore size of CeO2/AC also decreased. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of CeO2/AC samples before and after the reaction. The same diffraction peaks appeared at 28.5o, 33.08o, 47.5o, and 56.5o before and after the reaction, which respectively corresponds to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) crystal planes of cerium oxide with a cubic fluorite structure. However, the peak intensity greatly decreased in the XRD pattern of CeO2/AC after the reaction, and a new bulge appeared at about 20o. This peak may have been due to the adsorption of coke formed by lignin on the catalyst's surface after the catalytic reaction, so the used CeO2/AC had a lower crystallinity than the fresh sample. To further understand the surface structure of CeO2/AC materials, the samples were observed by SEM (Fig. 2 ). CeO2/AC samples prepared by the impregnation method were uniformly distributed on the activated carbon without agglomeration. XPS can identify the surface chemical state of the catalyst, the metal oxide metal state, and the type of oxygen (lattice oxygen or adsorbed oxygen), so this technique was used to characterize the valence state of Ce on the catalyst surface and the type of surface oxygen. Due to the double oxidation state of the Ce element in CeO2 and the mixing of O 2p, the XPS spectrum of Ce was complex. The XPS spectra of the two catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 . A series of small peaks were fitted from the spectra, and these small peaks were from two sets of spin-orbit multiple peaks. The ten peaks were labeled as v0, u0, v1, u1 for Ce(III), and u, v, u2, v2, u3, v3 for Ce(IV), where u and v refer to the 3d 5/2 and 3d3 /2 spin-orbital components, respectively. Subdividing these ten small peaks [u, v, u2, v2, u3, v3] represents the 3d 104f 0 electron orbital of Ce4+, while [v0, u0, v1, u1] represents the 3d 104f 1 electron orbital of Ce3+ [34]. Comparing the binding energy corresponding to the peak of Ce3+ in CeO2/AC and CeO2, the highest binding energy corresponding to the Ce3+ peak of the two catalysts was slight different (CeO2/AC v0: 881.36 eV, u0: 885.77 eV, v1: 898.92 eV, u1: 903.32 eV; CeO2 v0: 881.75 eV, u0: 885.87 eV, v1: 899.35 eV, u1: 908.21 eV) [35,36]. The highest binding energy of the Ce3+ peak in the CeO2/AC catalyst was slightly lower than the Ce3+ peak of CeO2. Therefore, we speculate that Ce3+ may have interacted with C. Moreover, the concentration of Ce3+ on the surface of the catalyst sample was closely related to the concentration of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface because more oxygen vacancies were needed to maintain the electrostatic balance of the catalyst as the concentration of Ce3+ increased [37]. Therefore, a higher Ce3+ concentration may have produced more oxygen vacancies on the catalyst. Therefore, [Ce3+/Ce3+ + Ce4+] was used to calculate the concentration of Ce3+ in the two catalysts, as shown in Table 1 . Table 1 shows that the Ce3+ concentration of CeO2/AC was significantly higher than that of CeO2, so it can be concluded that there were more surface oxygen vacancies on CeO2/AC than on CeO2. The same conclusion was obtained from the O 1 s XPS spectrum. Oxygen vacancies can act as Lewis acid sites during hydrogenation reactions, which weaken the Cβ-O bond when a molecule is adsorbed on the active site [38]. Zhao et al. also confirmed that oxygen vacancies on ceria could dissociate methanol to form methoxy and active hydrogen [19], which provides an essential basis for the performance of CeO2/AC catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic depolymerization of lignin model molecules Bolm and co-workers reported the catalytic depolymerization of lignin by using an oxidation-hydrogenation strategy [39]. They reduced the dissociation energy of the β-O-4 bond from 297.2 kJ·mol−1 to 215.6 kJ·mol−1 by selectively oxidizing Cα-OH to Cα=O [40], which significantly improved the degree of catalytic cleavage of β-O-4 bonds. The critical problem of the oxidation-reduction strategy is the selectivity of the second hydrogenolysis step. The most important feature of the catalyst is its ability to selectively catalytically crack β-O-4 bonds instead of hydrogenating aromatic rings or forming Cα-OH. Therefore, the model molecule 2-(2-methoxyphenoxy)-1-phenylethan-1-one (labeled as substrate 1) was selected, and methanol was used as the solvent to react for 4 h at 200°C. The activity of the catalyst for hydrogenolysis was investigated, and the results are shown in Table 2 . As shown in Table 2, the substrate was 2- (2-methoxyphenoxy)-1-phenylethan-1-one, and the reaction was performed for 4 hours in 25 ml methanol, 1 MPa argon atmosphere, and at 200 °C. When there was no catalyst or when only activated carbon was used as the catalyst (entries 1, 2), no substrate conversion was detected. This indicates that compound 1 was stable under the inert gas atmosphere and was not prone to thermal self-decomposition reactions. The use of 10% Pd/C catalyst (commercially available) depolymerized 40.3% of lignin (entry 3), while the common 10% Ni/C [41] catalyst had only a depolymerization effect of 20.6% (entry 4). However, both showed selectivity for guaiacol and acetophenone. When pure cerium oxide was added to the system as a catalyst, the substrate conversion rate was only 7.4% (entry 5). Still, a high selectivity for guaiacol and acetophenone was obtained, which indicated that CeO2 had a specific catalytic activity for β-O-4 bonds. Under the same reaction conditions, the CeO2/AC catalyst significantly increased the conversion of the substrate to a maximum of 98.5% (entry 10). The main pyrolysis products were guaiacol, acetophenone, and phenyl propanone, with yields of 79.5%, 64.2%, and 12.2%, respectively. Under the same preparation and catalytic conditions, the catalysts prepared by other oxides (such as MgAlOx, Al2O3) supported on activated carbon exhibited a meager conversion rate for compound 1 (entries 6, 7). Pr6O11/AC and Nd2O3/AC catalysts exhibited a high conversion rate of about 90% for compound 1, but the product selectivity was lower than that of CeO2/AC. Therefore, this paper focuses on CeO2/AC catalyst. Table 4 shows that a small amount of substrate 1 was reduced to alcohol compound 2 (yield 2.1%, as shown in entry 10), and 2-(2-methoxyphenoxy)-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one (compound 3) was also generated (yield 17.2%, as shown in entry 10). According to the product distribution, the Cβ-H of substrate 1 was activated during the reaction under catalysis by CeO2/AC. At the same time, the solvent methanol produced hydroxymethyl group that attacked the activated Cβ-H at the Cβ site to form 3-hydroxy-2-(2-methoxyphenoxy)-1-phenylpropane-1-one (compound 7). Then, one molecule of water was removed to form 2- (2-methoxyphenoxy) -1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one (compound 3). The effect of solvent on the reaction was also investigated. Methanol in the reaction system was replaced by benzene, acetonitrile, xylene, and toluene. The conversion rates showed that the reaction did not occur (entries 12–14) in these solvents. However, when ethanol and ethylene glycol were used, the conversion rates of the substrates were 95.2% and 58.5%, respectively (entries 15, 16). Still, the product selectivity could be further improved than the methanol solvent. Compared with alcohol solvents, benzene, acetonitrile, xylene, and toluene are aprotic solvents that do not produce protons capable of participating in hydrogenolysis reactions under these conditions, which may be a key factor that resulted in unconverted substrate. We also discussed the influence of the reaction atmosphere. Keeping other conditions unchanged, the substrate conversion and product selectivity did not change significantly after changing the argon gas to 1 MPa H2 (entry 17), indicating that CeO2/AC had a limited ability to activate molecular hydrogen. Any active hydrogen likely did not come from gaseous hydrogen, but rather from the methanol solvent. Under the same reaction conditions, methanol was replaced with acetonitrile, and then gaseous hydrogen (entry 18) was added as the hydrogen source. The substrate did not undergo catalytic conversion, which also confirmed the above results. The transformation of methanol to active hydrogen is thermodynamically more feasible than gaseous hydrogen because methanol's C-H bond dissociation energy is 96.1 kcal/mol, and the H-H bond dissociation energy of gaseous hydrogen is 104.2 kcal/mol [42]. Therefore, methanol is more likely to form active hydrogen than gaseous hydrogen. From a kinetics point of view, the methanol solvent can more easily contact active catalytic sites to generate active hydrogen because gaseous H2 needs to overcome the mass transfer resistance from a gas to a liquid and then from a liquid to a solid to be activated. Therefore, methanol is more accessible during activation than gaseous H2 [43–45]. Using solvents as a source of activated hydrogen will also make lignin cheaper during refining. The non-noble metal catalyst, CeO2/AC, showed moderate activity, which prevented hydrogenation of the benzene ring and also avoided the conversion of β-O-4 ketones to β-O-4 alcohols. This guaranteed the depolymerization of lignin by this oxidation-reduction strategy. The selective cracking effect of the CeO2/AC catalyst on different substituted model molecules of β-O-4-ketone was studied to verify the catalyst's universality. As shown in Table 3 , > 90% conversion was obtained by cracking different β-O-4 type lignin model compounds, and no aromatic ring hydrogenation products were detected. CeO2/AC selectively catalyzed the reductive cleavage of the Cβ-O-Ar bond, without changing the ether bond of the methoxy group connected to the aromatic ring. The table shows that the presence of a hydroxymethyl group at the Cβ position of the model molecule increased the reaction activity. The aromatic group at the β-O-4 bond of lignin usually contains a methoxy group; therefore, the current system may be more suitable for the pyrolysis of real lignin samples without a gaseous hydrogen source. The model molecule 2-(2-methoxyphenoxy)-1-phenylethyl-1-ketone (compound 1) is the simplest lignin model molecule, while in the β-O-4 bond of real lignin, there may be a hydroxymethyl group at the Cβ position. Therefore, using model molecules containing Cβ-hydroxymethyl groups during lignin depolymerization can better represent the real structure of lignin. Compound 7 was formed during the depolymerization of compound 1. Therefore, compound 7 was used as a substrate for the experiment. The results in entry 19 show that the conversion rate of model compound 7 was higher than that of model compound 1, and the reduction from β-O-4 ketone to β-O-4 alcohol was only 0.2%, which was much lower than the 2.1% of model compound 1. If Cα=O is hydrogenated back to Cα-OH, the dissociation energy of the C-O bond will be significantly increased, making it difficult to break, so it is necessary to limit the conversion of ketones to alcohols. These data show that by using CeO2/AC to catalyze the depolymerization of model compound 7 (whose structure is more similar to lignin's structure), Cα=O was hardly reduced to Cα-OH, which was beneficial to the subsequent depolymerization of lignin. 3.3 Catalytic depolymerization of real lignin According to the work of Stahl's group [33], lignin's Cα-OH group was selectively converted to the corresponding ketones by the O2/AcNH-TEMPO/HCl/HNO3 system. The lignin before and after oxidation was characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 4 in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. The characteristic absorption bands of methoxy and benzene rings in pre-oxidized lignin at 2854 cm−1, 1635 cm−1, 1604 cm−1, 1514 cm−1, 1460 cm−1, 1267 cm−1, 1120 cm−1, and 830 cm−1 indicated that the core structure of lignin was well preserved [45]. However, the tensile vibration absorption band intensity of the carbonyl group at 1705 cm−1 in the pre-oxidized mildly acidic hydrolyzed poplar lignin was significantly enhanced, indicating the successful selective oxidation of weakly acidic hydrolyzed poplar lignin [45]. A similar method was used to prepare pre-oxidized lignin samples isolated from poplar, birch, pine, and cotton stalks. The catalytic performance of CeO2/AC for the hydrogenolysis of pre-oxidized lignin obtained from poplar was studied. After 4 h of reaction at 220 °C, 1 MPa Ar, MeOH solvent, brown soluble oil-like products were obtained. The qualitative and quantitative analysis of lignin monomers in oily products was carried out using GC-MS. The results showed that CeO2/AC produced a series of phenolic monomers after catalytic hydrogenolysis of pre-oxidized lignin, with a total yield of 32.6 wt.%. The catalytic hydrogenolysis of pine, birch, and cotton stalk pre-oxidized lignin was also carried out under the same conditions. GC-MS was used to analyze the products, and the obtained phenolic monomers are shown in Fig. 5 . The gel chromatography curves showed that the molecular weight of poplar lignin shifted to the lower molecular weight region after the catalytic reaction. The pre-oxidized poplar lignin formed a prominent peak at the same retention volume of the monomer compound, indicating effective depolymerization. A data summary is given in Fig. 6 . In this paper, four types of plant lignin were selected: lignin from pine represents the guaiacol propane lignin (G lignin); the lignin from poplar and birch was composed of guaiacol propane and syringyl propane, referred to as GS lignin. Cotton stalk was representative of gramineous plants. In addition to guaiacyl propane and syringyl propane, there was more p-hydroxyphenyl propane, called GSH lignin. Under the same conditions, the CeO2/AC catalyst was used for the hydrogenolysis of birch, pine, and cotton stalk pre-oxidized lignin, and the total yield of phenolic monomers was 31.2 wt.%, 17.4 wt.%, and 12.1 wt.%, respectively. The types and yields of depolymerization products obtained after quantitative and qualitative analysis by GC-MS are listed in Tables 4 and S4. Table 4 shows that the derivatives of syringyl (S) monomer mainly included 2,6-dimethoxy-4-propenylphenol (S5), 2,6-dimethoxy-4- (2-propenyl) phenol (S6), and syringylpropane (S4). The guaiacyl (G) monomer derivatives mainly included 4-propenyl-2-methoxyphenol (G7) and 4-propylguaiacol (G4). The syringyl (S) monomer derivatives mainly included phenol and methyl 4-hydroxybenzoate. According to the characteristics of the lignin model compound's catalytic reaction and lignin depolymerization monomer products, a reaction pathway was proposed, as shown in Scheme 2 . Lignin was extracted by weak acidic hydrolysis under mild conditions, and this extraction method retained the intact structure of lignin than when it was extracted under other harsh conditions. First, the extracted lignin was selectively converted into corresponding ketones by O2/AcNH-TEMPO/HCl/HNO3 at 60 °C for 24 h. The pre-oxidized lignin remained as a high-molecular-weight polymer that was then depolymerized by CeO2/AC into dimers and trimers containing β-O-4 bonds. Some Cγ-OH in the dimer was dehydrated to form unsaturated ketones, and then the β-O-4 bonds were broken to form ketone monomers. Under the action of CeO2/AC, methanol was activated to form active hydrogen, and benzyl alcohol monomers were formed under the catalysis of active hydrogen. Finally, unsaturated aromatic monomers were formed by dehydration. The cyclic experimental results are shown in the appendix. After three cycles, the activity of the CeO2/AC catalyst decreased only slightly. 4 Conclusion The CeO2/AC catalyst prepared by an impregnation method showed promising activity during the hydrogenolysis of lignin. XPS spectra demonstrated that the surface oxygen vacancy concentration of the CeO2/AC catalyst was higher than that of CeO2. Oxygen vacancies acted as Lewis acid sites during the hydrogenation reaction, which weakened the Cβ-O bond when an oxygen molecule was adsorbed onto active sites. Oxygen vacancies on cerium oxide dissociated methanol to form methoxy radical and active hydrogen. The electron-rich carrier-activated carbon was more conducive to electron transfer and showed a high activity. Through the two-step pre-oxidation-reduction strategy, the CeO2/AC catalyst selectively reduced and cracked the Cβ-O-Ar bond in lignin in the methanol system under an inert gas atmosphere. The products were mainly phenols, and the reverse hydrogenation side reaction of the ketone bond was rare. The results of hydrogenolysis of various model molecules show that CeO2/AC was also suitable for multiple compounds with substituted Cβ-O-Ar ether bonds and offered a high activity and selectivity. CeO2/AC was extended to the mild acidolysis of lignin from different sources (pine, cotton stalk, birch, and poplar), in which the catalyst still displayed a high yield of phenolic monomers. The total yield of lignin from different sources reached 12.1–32.6 wt.%. GPC analysis showed that CeO2/AC also reduced the molecular weight of residual lignin. coredata.dc:description: There are limited renewable sources of aromatic chemicals, with lignin being one of the most prominent, accounting for approximately 30% of the planet's organic carbon. Due to its intricate and irregular structure, lignin is recalcitrant to chemical conversion, often resulting in low yields of mixtures of products when it is depolymerized. This study synthesized a CeO2/AC catalyst via an impregnation technique and then explored its ability to depolymerize lignin via an oxidation-reduction strategy. The CeO2/AC catalyst efficiently depolymerized lignin by an oxidation-reduction strategy. At 200 °C, an argon pressure of 1 MPa, and a reaction time of 4 h, the conversion of the lignin model compound reached 98.5%. When using lignin derived from poplar, birch, pine, and cotton stalk, the total yields of phenolic monomers were 36.2 wt.%, 31.2 wt.%, 17.4 wt.%, and 12.1 wt.%, respectively. The CeO2/AC catalyst exhibited a higher surface oxygen vacancy concentration than CeO2, which was crucial for facilitating the hydrogenolysis of lignin.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient hydrogenolysis of lignin over CeO2/AC catalyst prepared by a simple impregnation method
